metadata.title: Evaluation of mechanical and durability properties of fiber-reinforced lightweight geopolymer composites based on rice husk ash and nano-alumina

Evaluation of mechanical and durability properties of fiber-reinforced lightweight geopolymer composites based on rice husk ash and nanoalumina

Ehsan Mohseni a,⇑, Mahyar Jafar Kazemi b, Mahdi Koushkbaghi c, Behnam Zehtab d, Babak Behforouz e a School of Architecture and Built Environment, The University of Newcastle, Callaghan, NSW 2308, Australia bDepartment of Civil Engineering, Islamic Azad University, West Tehran Branch, Tehran, Iran cDepartment of Civil Engineering, University of Hormozgan, Qeshm, Iran dDepartment of Technology and Engineering, Shahid Ashrafi Esfahani University, Esfahan, Iran eDepartment of Civil Engineering, Dehaghan Branch, Islamic Azad University, Dehaghan, Iran
h i g h l i g h t s
Geopolymer concretes were synthesized using rice husk ash and nano alumina. Properties of fiber-reinforced lightweight geopolymer concretes were assessed. PP fibers improved the mechanical properties, especially flexural strength. Lightweight geopolymer concrete were suitable for structural applications.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 6 February 2019 Received in revised form 5 March 2019 Accepted 8 March 2019
Keywords: Geopolymer Rice husk ash Nano-Al2O3 Polypropylene fiber Lightweight aggregate Scoria
a b s t r a c t
In the current study, the physical and mechanical properties of polypropylene fiber-reinforced lightweight geopolymer concretes are assessed. Geopolymer synthesis consists of rice husk ash (RHA) and nano-Al2O3 (NA) as solid precursors and 10 M sodium hydroxide (SH) and sodium silicate (SS) with a ratio of SS/SH = 2.5 as alkaline solution. NA amount is 20% of total volume of the binder for all mixtures. Scoria particles are used as lightweight aggregates (LWA) with replacement ratio of 0, 10 and 20% by volume of the total aggregates. Polypropylene (PP) fibers is added to the mixture with the amount of 0, 0.5 and 1% by the volume of the binder. Compressive and flexural strength, density, water absorption and rapid chloride permeability test (RCPT) were evaluated. Results indicated that PP fibers improves the mechanical properties (especially flexural strength) while incorporation of LWA reduced the compressive and flexural strength slightly. Water absorption of geopolymer samples decreased by the incorporation of PP fibers which can compensate significantly the negative impact of LWA replacement. Replacement of 10% LWA does not have significant impact on water absorption and chloride permeability of composites; however, 20% replacement reduced durability. Introduced lightweight geopolymer concrete would be suitable for structural applications due to its relatively low density, high compressive strength and good flexural strength, which is improved by adding PP fibers.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Cement production industry concerns with environmental issues and huge energy dissipation. It has the third rank in both greenhouse gases emission and energy consumption. For one ton of cement, about one ton of carbon dioxide is released in the air which is 5–7% of total carbon dioxide emission in the world
[1,2]. Moreover there is an ever-increasing need for cement in the world so that about three tons of concrete would be consumed annually per one human living on the earth and its usage is in second rank after water around the world [3]. Therefore, it is required to use alternative materials for reducing cement consumption. One of the most recent alternative compounds is alkali-activated cement named geopolymer. Geopolymer is an aluminosilicate polymer formed in alkaline environment. Due to their low carbon footprint, these inorganic polymers can be considered as green alternatives to Portland cement. The general form of phase
compositions in aluminosilicate products is R-A-S-H (R = Na+ or K+) [4] with amorphous to semi-crystalline polymeric and ring structure including sialate bond (Si-O-Al) and siloxo bond (Si-O-Si) [5]. Atomic structure of alkali-activated cementitious materials is relatively complex and molecular dynamics (MD) method provides more precise information about atomic structure and properties of different types of cementitious materials such as C-S-H [6–8], cement clinker phases [9] as well as geopolymers [10,11].
Geopolymers are formed based on minimally activated natural minerals such as metakaolin or agricultural and industrial byproducts like fly ash (FA), rice husk ash (RHA) and blast furnace slag [12]. Consuming waste materials as precursor in geopolymerization has two advantages for making eco-friendly concrete: developing zero-cement concrete mixture and prevention of wastes accumulation in nature. Geopolymer has attractive properties such as better compressive strength, better heat resistance, less permeability and good resistance to acid and salt environments, which has led many researchers to study the properties of this material [13–17]. The three most common raw material used in geopolymerization are slags, calcined clays and ashes which are studied widely as supplementary cementitious materials in Portland cement-based mixtures [18–21]. A precursor with high aluminum content could be suitable to be implemented in geopolymerization, only if a high proportion of its aluminum content is released in the reaction [22]. Release rate of aluminum depends on the chemical structure of precursor material, alkali concentration and alkaline solution type [23,24]. Fly ash (FA) and metakaolin (MK) have been widely studied as geopolymer precursor. Chindaprasirt et al. [25] used sodium hydroxide and sodium silicate and heat for activation of class C fly ash-based geopolymer synthesis. They concluded that concentration of sodium hydroxide has no considerable effect on the strength. Somna et al. [26] indicated that ground fly ash (GFA) has a higher rate of reaction and geopolymer synthesis made by GFA with a median particle size of 10.5 lm required less activation practice, so that it could be activated in ambient temperature. Ilkentapar et al. [27] revealed that NaOH-activated geopolymer synthesis made by class F fly ash has higher compressive and flexural strength. Moreover they indicated that mortar samples with longer curing period have higher water absorption and it was increased after extra rest period but with a lower rate comparing to samples with shorter curing period in the oven. Rovnanik [28] showed that curing at elevated temperatures accelerates the strengths development for metakaolinbased geopolymer samples. Kong et al. [29] revealed that fly ashbased geopolymers have more small pores in comparison to metakaolin-based geopolymers which it helps the moisture to release easily under elevated temperature and make the geopolymer matrix with minimal damages. Duan et al. [30] indicated that compressive and flexural strength of the metakaolin-based geopolymer decrease with increasing polystyrene particle content.
In recent years RHA has been used for making geopolymer synthesis [31]. RHA is an agricultural by-product material remained in the combustion process of rice husk that is a green waste with net zero carbon footprint. Gross rice is produced about 545 million metric ton of the worldwide annually and rice husk is one fifth of this amount which remains as waste [32]. Rice husk has a low commercial value and handling and transportation problem due to its low density. Much of the produced rice husk is burnt in open fields which causes environmental and health problems in surrounding residential areas [33]. Therefore it is necessary to utilize rice husk ash in a Sustainable manner [34]. RHA includes noncrystalline silicon dioxide with high reactivity and high specific surface area [35] which is widely used as a supplementary material in cement-based mixtures [36–40]. Detphan and Chindaprasirt [41] prepared fly ash and RHA-based geopolymer mixtures using sodium hydroxide and sodium silicate as alkaline activators.
Hwang and Huynh [42] illustrated that optimum geopolymer synthesis with the highest compressive strength (about 35.4 MPa) was obtained with a RHA content of 35% in fly ash and RHA-based geopolymers. Eduardo et al. [43] obtained optimum compressive strength of NaOH-activated geopolymer samples made by metakaolin and RHA. Another approach for geopolymer synthesizing is one-part formulation or ‘‘just add water” geopolymers which solid form of alkaline activator would be mixed by solid aluminosilicate precursors [44,45]. Sturm et al. [46] introduced a onepart geopolymer synthesis from RHA and sodium aluminate with compressive strength of about 30 MPa. Sore et al. [47] showed that 5% partial substitution of metakaolin by RHA promotes the development of the amorphous phase of geopolymers and leads to 87% increase in mechanical strength.
To improve shrinkage, low fracture energy and brittleness of geopolymer samples polypropylene (PP) fiber can be used due to its high toughness and anticorrosion [48,49]. Zhang et al. [48] found that geopolymers made by metakaolin and fly ash containing PP fiber have the compressive and flexural strength higher than geopolymers without PP. Moreover, shrinkage and modulus of compressibility in geopolymers containing 0.05% PP fiber are 38.6% and 31.3% lower than ordinary geopolymers, respectively. Ranjbar et al. [50] showed that incorporation of PP fibers up to 3 wt% into the fly ash-geopolymer mixture decreases the shrinkage and increases the energy absorption of the samples. Lowry and Kriven [51] improved tensile strength of metakaolin-based sodium metasilicate-activated geopolymer samples by PP fibers, significantly.
Geopolymer concrete similar to Portland cement-based concrete has a density about 2400 kg/m3 that can be reduced by partial replacement of aggregates by lightweight aggregates (LWA). Abdullah et al. [52] conducted an experimental study to assess the properties of lightweight geopolymer concrete. They made geopolymer samples by class C fly ash as precursor and sodium silicate and sodium hydroxide as alkaline activator solution. Hu et al. [53] revealed that compressive strength of their geopolymer lightweight concrete samples made by metakaolin. Posi et al. [54] used aggregates obtained from crushing the recycle lightweight blocks in fly ash-based geopolymers. They found that lightweight samples have a compressive strength of 1–16 MPa, density of 860–1400 kg/ m3 and water absorption of 10–31% after curing in oven for 48 h and then, in ambient conditions for 28 days. Abdulkareem et al. [55] indicated that lightweight fly ash-based geopolymer concrete samples have a higher compressive strength in the case of unexposed specimens to elevated temperature than cured samples in oven due to good bonding between aggregate and geopolymer mortar at the interface transition zone.
Nanoparticles such as nano-SiO2 [56,57], nano-Al2O3 (NA) [56–58] and TiO2 [59], CuO [60], SnO2, ZrO2, CaCO3 [61], Cr2O3 and ZnO2 [62] nanoparticles have major effects on mechanical properties and durability of the cementitious mixtures. Addition of NA could improve mechanical properties of cementitious pastes due to the formation of extra calcium silicate hydrate (C-S-H) or calcium aluminosilicate hydrate (C-A-S-H) and sodium aluminosilicate hydrate (N-A-S-H) or geopolymer gel in alkali-activated matrix [56,57]. Especially for geopolymerization based on lowaluminum materials like RHA, it is essential to add highaluminum materials such as NA to the mixture.
In this paper geopolymer concrete are synthesized using RHA and NA as precursor and alkaline solution consists of sodium silicate and sodium hydroxide with the ratio of Na2SiO3/NaOH = 2.5 as activator. Aggregates used in the mixtures are partially replaced by scoria as LWA. Moreover, PP fibers are added to the pastes for reducing the brittleness of the geopolymer samples and NA particles is considered for all mix designs for enhancing the strength of geopolymer samples and to make them more durable. After
28-day curing in ambient temperature, the samples are tested to obtain the compressive and flexural strength, density, water absorption and rapid chloride permeability test (RCPT). The effects of incorporation of LWA and PP fibers are assessed on the mechanical, physical properties and durability of alkali-activated samples.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Rice husk ash (RHA) is an agricultural by-product which it is produced by burning rice husk as fuel for drying rice, due to its high calorific power (about 16720 kJ/kg). Rice husk weight is approximately 30% of gross weight of its kernel and it loses its weight up to about 80% after transformation into RHA. It consists of 20% of inorganic and 80% of organic substances. RHA meets the requirements of standards [56] for considering as pozzolanic materials. RHA has high silica content because rice plant adsorbs silica from the soils and stores it in its grains and husks covering the grains. The amount of silica in RHA depends on inorganic impurities in its initial composition. To identify chemical composition of RHA, XRD test was conducted on RHA powder substances. As it is shown in Fig. 1 most of the RHA structure composed of silica (about 91% of total mass) which is illustrated with quartz. Consumed RHA material in this research has the chemical composition and physical properties as tabulated in Table 1. Rice husk ash was produced by burning rice husk in furnace at increasing controlled temperature which was not exceed 700 C. The temperature was increased with a rate of 200 C per hour until it reached the final temperature of 700 C over a period of 3.5 h. The temperature was kept at 700 C for 1 h and residue ash was cooled in controlled condition and grinded in Los Angeles mill with 1000 grinding cycles.
NA particles are considered with the mount of 20% of total volume of the mixture for all geopolymer synthesis based on some preliminary trials. NA can compensate the lack of aluminum oxide in RHA for making geopolymer mixture. In this study, NA with an average particle size of 20 nm in dispersed suspension form is considered for making the geopolymer matrix. Used NA in this research has a purity of higher than 98% and specific surface area of 200 m2/g. The scanning electron micrographs (SEM) is implemented to find out the shape of RHA and NA particles. As it is clear in Fig. 2, NA and RHA particles have the spherical and irregular shape, respectively.
Alkaline solution was composed of 10 M sodium hydroxide (SH) and sodium silicate (SS) with a constant ratio of SS/SH = 2.5 for all geopolymer synthesis. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution was
prepared by dissolving the analytical grade of sodium hydroxide pellets with a purity of 99%. Water glass solution (sodium silicate) with a modulus of SiO2/Na2O = 2.06 and mass fraction of SiO2 = 31.7%, Na2O = 15.4% and water = 52.9%.
Aggregates used in the experimental tests are categorized into three parts: fine aggregates, ordinary and lightweight coarse aggregates. Natural river sand and limestone gravel are considered as fine and ordinary coarse aggregates, respectively and scoria (Crushed basaltic-pumice) was replaced the coarse aggregates with a ratio of 0, 10 and 20% by volume of the aggregates (see Fig. 3). Coarse and fine aggregates have the water absorption of 0.69 and 1.2% and their nominal maximum particle size are 12.5 and 4.75 mm, respectively. The coarse aggregates were used in SSD condition (saturated and surface dry) in the mixture.
PP fibers were used in the geopolymer mixture with a diameter of 20 mm, a length of 6 mm, and an aspect ratio of 300 with the amount of 0, 0.5 and 1% of the binder volume (Fig. 4). The PP fibers are durable in severe ambient conditions such as freezing, corrosive and chemical leaching environment. Physical properties of PP fibers are given in Table 2.

sections.heading: 2.2. Experimental methods
sections.text:
Precursor materials for synthesizing geopolymers were mixed according to mix proportions given in Table 3. Mix labels are adjusted based on the amount of PP fibers and LWA. The numbers next to the PP or LWA letters indicate the percentage of these materials. In all of the mixes, the amount of RHA, NA, SS, SH and sand are constant and the liquid to solid (L/S) ratio of 0.45 is considered.
In this research RHA powder was obtained by burning the rice husk pellets through an electric kiln at temperatures of 500–700 C in a heating rate of 5 C/min for 6 h. In order to ensure about preparing a uniform alkaline solution, NaOH and water glass solutions were mixed 24 h prior to use in the mixture. River sand, limestone and LWAwere initially dry mixed in the pan mixer. After 1–2 min RHA was added to the mixer and still dry mixed for extra 2–3 min. Finally, alkaline solution, NA and PP fibers were gradually added to the mixer and all of the precursor materials were mixed for 2–3 min until a uniform geopolymer synthesis was prepared. In Fig. 5 cross section of sample, containing LWA has been shown. As it is clear, red and grey particles are scoria and limestone gravels, respectively.
Two types of specimens were made for further analysis on the mechanical and physical properties of hardened geopolymer samples. Cylindrical samples with dimensions of 20 10 cm were prepared for testing compressive strength and water absorption, and prism specimens with dimensions of 10 10 80 cm were fabricated for flexural strength test. In the RCPT, the total charge passing through a concrete disc after 90 days of ambient curing with 50 mm in thickness and 100 mm in diameter was evaluated in
6 h by 60 V’ potential in accordance with ASTM C1202 [57]. Samples were demoulded after 24 h and cured at ambient temperature of 20 ± 2 C. Curing periods for density determination and compressive and flexural strength tests were 28 days while the other specimens were cured for 90 days before water absorption test and RCPT. Three samples were manufactured for each test and their results were averaged out so that 54 cylindrical and 27 prism specimens were constructed.

sections.heading: 3.1. Density and compressive strength
sections.text:
The cylindrical samples at the age of 28 days was tested firstly to determine their densities according to ASTM-C138 [58]. The same samples were then tested for determination their compressive strength in accordance with ASTM-C109 [59].
As it is shown in Fig. 6 density of lightweight geopolymer concrete samples were decreased to the minimum value of 1865 kg/ m3 for LWA20 samples. In Fig. 7 the variation of compressive strength of cylindrical samples with different percentages of LWA and PP fibers are shown. As it is clear in Fig. 7, there is a slight loss of strength (maximum 6.5% in PP0.5-LWA20 samples) due to increasing the amount of LWA which can be attributed to the porous nature of LWA. By considering Figs. 6 and 7, lightweight geopolymer samples in present research for LWA replacement ratio of 0.1–0.2 have the density of 1865–1985 kg/m3 and the compressive strength of 50–53 MPa. Habibi et al. [60] have found the density of lightweight Portland cement-based concrete about 1878–2075 kg/m3 corresponds to LWA replacement ratio of 0.6–0.8 and compressive strength of 28–43 MPa. Shannag et al. [61] developed lightweight Portland cement-based concrete using scoria with replacement ratio of 0.78 and they obtained density of the samples in the range of 1739–1914 kg/m3 corresponding to the compressive strength of 18–48 MPa. Farahani et al. [62] revealed

that ternary blend Portland cement, RHA and fly ash containing oil palm shell as aggregate has a density of 1600–2000 kg/m3 and compressive strength of 18.5–40 MPa. Posi et al. [44] found the density of 1099–1336 kg/m3 and compressive strength of 1–14 MPa for lightweight geopolymer samples made by fly ash and aggregate from recycle lightweight blocks. Kupaei et al. [63] showed that geopolymer mixture based on fly ash with incorporation of oil palm shell as aggregate have a compressive strength in a range of 9.6–28.4 MPa and density of 1396–2052 kg/m3. In this study, lightweight geopolymer concrete samples have reasonable compressive strength and considerably low density. As it is
mentioned in ACI manual for structural lightweight-aggregate concrete [64] and ASTM C-567 [65] density of structural lightweight concrete is between 1800–1900 kg/m3 and its compressive strength must be in the range of 21–35 MPa for common applications and above 35 MPa for precast and prestressed concrete. ASTM C-330 [66] expressed that for obtaining the compressive strength of 28 MPa, it is required to make concrete mixture with a density of lower than 1840 kg/m3 while in present research the samples with 20% incorporation of LWA have compressive strength of about 50 MPa and density of 1865–1879 kg/m3. Therefore, introduced mixture is suitable for structural applications to reduce the weight of the structure without losing strength. As it is illustrated in Fig. 7, PP fibers have an insignificant increasing effect (maximum 2.3% in PP1-LWA10 samples) on the compressive strength of geopolymer samples in present study.
In Table 4, the ratio of compressive strength to density for different types of cementitious mixtures are compared. As it is revealed in Table 4, results obtained from present study have the most compressive strength (f’c) to density (q) ratio, consequently the introduced mixture is the most efficient lightweight concrete among the provided works.
It is possible to relate compressive strength to density of cementitious mixtures. By comparing Figs. 6 and 7 it can be discovered that the samples with higher densities have a greater compressive strength. In Fig. 8 a polynomial trend line with the order of 2 and correlation coefficient of 0.75 is drawn to find a relation between compressive strength to density. Previous researchers have tried to find this relation for different types of lightweight concrete samples which are compared in Table 5.

sections.heading: 3.2. Water absorption
sections.text:
Cylindrical geopolymer samples after 90 days curing in ambient conditions were tested to determine water absorption accordance with ASTM C-642 [67]. Specimens were dried in the oven at a tem-
perature of 100–110 C for 24 h. They were allowed to be cooled in the air and the mass of the specimens were determined. Then, the specimens were saturated in water for 48 h at approximately 21 C and they were weighed after drying their surfaces. Water absorption was determined using the ratio of mass of the water adsorbed in saturated case to mass of the dry specimen. As it is indicated in

sections.heading: 3.3. Flexural strength
sections.text:
Beam specimens were tested according to ASTM C-78 [69] using third-point loading machine after 28 days curing in ambient conditions. In Fig. 11 variation of flexural strength with the amount of PP fibers is presented. Results indicate that PP fibers increase the flexural strength. Flexural strength indirectly presents the tensile capacity and flexural strength improvement in current research is due to fiber effects on the tensile strength. Flexural strength of metakaolin-based geopolymer can raised to 38 MPa after 25 days [70] and FA-based and FA/RHA-based samples may have flexural strength of 8.1 [71] and 13 MPa [72] respectively, while in this study RHA and NA-based geopolymer sample containing LWA and PP fibers have flexural strength of 6.4–9.8 MPa. Results from the literature [49] shows that incorporation of RHA and NA as supplementary materials in Portland cement-based mixtures containing PP fibers leads to provide a mixture with flexural strength of 5.81–9.6 MPa which are comparable to geopolymeric mixture with similar raw materials synthesized in present research.
As it is shown in Fig. 11, flexural strength is higher for larger amounts of PP fibers in a sense that for the case of 1% PP fiber an increasing of 36.3%, 30.2% and 18.2% in flexural strength was observed for PP1, PP1-LWA10 and PP1-LWA20 samples, respectively. Similar to compressive strength, flexural strength was also decreased by increasing the amount of LWA. It is revealed that
PP1-LWA20 samples have a flexural strength about 30% lower than corresponding value for PP1 samples. Although the application of lightweight geopolymer concrete requires ignoring about 0.4– 6.4% of the compressive strength and 5.7–30.1% of the flexural strength, it is reasonable to use this type of concrete if the structural weight loss is critical.

sections.heading: 3.4. Rapid chloride permeability test
sections.text:
RCPT is one of the most useful and early returns methods for estimating durability of different kinds of hardened geopolymer and normal concrete. Rapid chloride permeability test results of the geopolymer composites at the age of 90 days have been plotted in Fig. 12. As can be seen, an increasing of up to 7.58% in chloride permeability was observed for PP1-LWA20, sample. Although the PP1-LWA20, PP0.5-LWA20 and LWA20 had the worst results compared with the other samples containing LWA, and belongs to the category of moderate chloride permeability (Charge passed between 2000 and 4000 coulombs), they still had a suitable amount of permeability compared to that of for the control sample. It can be inferred from the results that the replacement of 10% LWA did not increase the permeability significantly, but the increasing LWA replacement from 10 to 20%, had more impact on the permeability increase. It has been found from literature that the LWA
ixtures with the variation of PP fiber and LWA percentages.
increases the chloride permeability of lightweight geopolymer composites dramatically, though the results of this study indicated that this negative impact was not that significant. The reason could be due to the using rice husk ash and nano-Al2O3 as solid precursors which could improve the chloride permeability of paste.
It should be noted that the addition of fibers to lightweight geopolymer composites had no significant effect on the durability of geopolymer composites against chloride ion penetration. In order to understand the relationship between the geopolymer composite characteristics, the compressive strength and RCPT results of geopolymer composites were presented in Fig. 13. It was found that the coefficient correlation between chloride permeability and compressive strength test results is relatively high with R2 of almost 0.87.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this research mechanical and physical properties of alkaliactivated RHA-based PP fiber-reinforced concrete containing NA and LWA were investigated. Density of geopolymer samples were reduced due to incorporation of LWA up to 14.5% and 21.2% corresponding to replacing of 10% and 20% natural aggregates by LWA, respectively.
Water absorption of geopolymer samples were varied subject to the variation of LWA and PP fiber incorporation. It was increased up to 9.8% and 21.4% in the case of samples with 10% and 20% replacement of natural coarse aggregates by scoria particles, respectively. Water absorption of tested samples with 0.5% and 1% PP fibers reduced up to 5.4% and 8.3% respectively.
The addition of scoria as LWA decreased the 28-day compressive strength of samples up to 3.8% and 6.5% from their original level when natural aggregates were replaced by 10% and 20% LWA. Addition of LWA had stronger effects on flexural strength than compressive strength. Flexural strength reduced up to 10.6% and 30.1% in the case of replacement of natural aggregates by 10% and 20% LWA, respectively.
Incorporation of 0.5% and 1% PP fiber increased the 28-day compressive strength of geopolymer samples up to 0.6% and 2.3%, while it was enhanced the 28-day flexural capacity of geopolymer samples up to 15.4% and 36.3% respectively. This conclusion is drawn that PP fibers has a considerable effect on flexural strength unlike the compressive strength, because of influences of fibers on tensile capacity of cementitious mixtures.
Slight reduction in compressive strength due to addition of LWA is negligible and the reduction in flexural strength caused by replacing natural aggregates by LWA could be controllable by adding fibers. Therefore because of less weight of lightweight geopolymer concrete, the application of it instead of ordinary geopolymer concrete might be justifiable.

metadata.abstractText: In the current study, the physical and mechanical properties of polypropylene fiber-reinforced lightweight geopolymer concretes are assessed. Geopolymer synthesis consists of rice husk ash (RHA) and nano-Al2O3 (NA) as solid precursors and 10 M sodium hydroxide (SH) and sodium silicate (SS) with a ratio of SS/SH = 2.5 as alkaline solution. NA amount is 20% of total volume of the binder for all mixtures. Scoria particles are used as lightweight aggregates (LWA) with replacement ratio of 0, 10 and 20% by volume of the total aggregates. Polypropylene (PP) fibers is added to the mixture with the amount of 0, 0.5 and 1% by the volume of the binder. Compressive and flexural strength, density, water absorption and rapid chloride permeability test (RCPT) were evaluated. Results indicated that PP fibers improves the mechanical properties (especially flexural strength) while incorporation of LWA reduced the compressive and flexural strength slightly. Water absorption of geopolymer samples decreased by the incorporation of PP fibers which can compensate significantly the negative impact of LWA replacement. Replacement of 10% LWA does not have significant impact on water absorption and chloride permeability of composites; however, 20% replacement reduced durability. Introduced lightweight geopolymer concrete would be suitable for structural applications due to its relatively low density, high compressive strength and good flexural strength, which is improved by adding PP fibers. 2019 Elsevier Ltd.
